comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] " ... scarlet tunics, long navy trousers, and gay caps." (The Advertiser, 26/01/1937, p. 23). I don't think those other uniforms you're alluding to were ever described that way.

comment.author: 27309380@N06
comment._content:
Sharp kids, wish uniforms were this handsome today. Nothing looks like this anymore... Uniforms are cut like tents and made of polyester. Back in these years they weren't so terrible, they actually looked sharp.

Uniforms were a major item in most places during this era. Anyone who worked in a "service" type job had one. Service stations, theaters ushers, milkmen, postmen, radio repairmen, doormen, bellmen, band musicians and so forth... The Nazi's didn't create uniforms, they embraced them like many cultures did of that time. They have just left an indelible mark on our minds and now uniforms are associated with a wicked, socialist party... Such a pity.

comment._content: What great looking uniforms and not something you see boys wearing today.

comment.author: 92807080@N00
comment._content: . The sharp uniforms popular with organizations in the 1930s were superseded by less stylish designs mainly to reduce production costs--not because the look had become stigmatized by association with Hitler's regime. After all, the armies that overthrew that regime also had dress uniforms with much the same features. If we are going to get picayune here, these boy band outfits have scalloped trim on the cuffs--a hallmark of 19th Century European military uniforms. No Third Reich uniform had scalloped trim, and the straight trim cuff which had been part of the German uniform since adopted by the Prussian military in the 1820s was eliminated in 1940. Moreover, these boy band blouses are notably short. The bottom of all Wehrmacht tunics matched the length of its sleeves. Perhaps the boys' peaked visor caps remind some people of the Wehrmacht's dress caps. No reason they should. Most organizations in the West adopted this design in the early 20th Century and continue to wear them, although the exaggerated height of the peak adopted by the USSR and other commie nations has always struck me as goofy looking. And speaking of goofy, you really must see the Leningrad Cowboys gonzo rock band and the Red Army Choir perform Sweet Home Alabama. Crank up the volume and prepare to smile: www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_detailpage&v=zKD... .

comment.author: 27309380@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/sixpounder] 

Very good points! You're accurate in your history Sixpounder, yet the average person today fallows the Kardashian's on TV and not the history of uniforms. I was amazed at my mother's reaction when I put on my WWII US Army Air Corps officers uniform for an event, she said I looked like Hitler! Wow Mom, really? I don't even wear a mustache and his uniforms were much more garish than that of the Air Corps! But, it's that so many have a very limited association to history and the rolls uniforms played. But, people like us know better and it's really important to set an example and educate. :)
